{{Infobox person | name = Juana Bordas | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1942}} | birth_place = [[Nicaragua]] | death_date = | nationality = | occupation = Community activist | employer = | years_active = 1976—present | known_for = Latino community activist, leadership training, diversity training | notable_works = ''Salsa, Soul, and Spirit: Leadership for a Multicultural Age'' (2007) }} '''Juana María Bordas''' (born 1942) is a [[Nicaraguan Americans|Nicaraguan–American]] community activist specializing in [[leadership development]] and [[diversity training]]. She is a founder of several [[Denver]], [[Colorado]]-area organizations promoting Latino and Latina leadership, including the Mi Casa Resource Center for Women, the National Hispana Leadership Institute, and Mestiza Leadership International, where she currently serves as president. She has authored two books and is a motivational speaker and workshop presenter for conferences and businesses. The recipient of numerous awards and honors, she was inducted into the [[Colorado Women's Hall of Fame]] in 1997. ==Early life and education== Juana María Bordas was born in a small mining town in Nicaragua in 1942.{{cite web |url= http://nbclatino.com/2013/07/01/latina-leaders-juana-bordas-and-her-new-book-the-power-of-latino-leadership/|title= Latina Leaders: Juana Bordas, and her new book, 'The Power of Latino Leadership'|first=Kristina|last=Puga|date=1 July 2013|accessdate=15 June 2017|work=NBC Latino}}{{cite book|last=Epstein|first=Vivian|title=History of Colorado's Women for Young People|date=1997|publisher=Vivian Sheldon Epstein|isbn=1891424009|page=52|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XTddUJzHWAAC&pg=PA52}} She is one of seven children. Her father left the family to earn money in the United States when she was a baby; at age 3, she and her older siblings and mother followed him to [[Tampa, Florida]], on a [[Banana boat (ship)|banana boat]].{{cite web |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-167025259.html|title=Executive edge: Juana Bordas; Author implores others to embrace work, heritage|first=Lynn|last=Bronikowski|date=1 July 2007|accessdate=15 June 2017|work=ColoradoBiz|subscription=yes|via=HighBeam}} She attended the [[Academy of the Holy Names (Florida)|Academy of the Holy Names]], a Catholic all-girls high school, on a scholarship, and babysat during Sunday services at a local church to cover the rest of her tuition.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.il/books?id=D7HFOU0hkaIC | title= Salsa, Soul, and Spirit: Leadership for a Multicultural Age|year=2012|edition=2nd revised|publisher=Berrett-Koehler Publishers |isbn=1576754324|page=2}} She was the first in her family to attend college.{{cite web|url=http://www.cogreatwomen.org/project/juana-bordas/|title=Juana Bordas|year=2016|publisher=[[Colorado Women's Hall of Fame]]|accessdate=14 June 2017}} She became involved in campus activism at the [[University of Florida]]; in 1963 she joined a march to the administration building to protest the non-enrollment of minority students.{{cite web |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-215719720.html|title=Leading Her Own Way: Mestiza Leadership's Juana Bordas|first=Laura|last=Rivas|date=1 October 2009|accessdate=15 June 2017|work=Latino Leaders|subscription=yes|via=[[HighBeam Research|HighBeam]]}} She earned her undergraduate degree at the University of Florida and her master's degree in social work at the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]]. Inspired by her parents, who believed that education was key to Latino advancement, and by President [[John F. Kennedy]], who spoke on campus about the need to "give back to your country", she joined the [[Peace Corps]] after completing her undergraduate degree. In [[Santiago]], Chile, she helped low-income men and women develop cooperative enterprises. Her 1964–1966 stint{{cite web |url=http://peacecorpsworldwide.org/review-power-of-latino-leadership/|title=Review: The Power of Latino Leadership by Juana Bordas (Chile 1964–66)|first=Jean|last=Seigle|year=2016|publisher=Peace Corps Worldwide}} afforded her the first exposure to Latinos in positions of leadership, both in the economic and political realms. ==Career== {{quote box |width=250px |align=right |bgcolor= |salign=right |quote= Historically, leadership has been hierarchical, the domain of the influential few, and associated with control and dominance. This type of leadership is not strategically suited for the global multicultural age where change is constant and our problems are very complex. People are better educated and want to participate. |source=–Juana Bordas }} Bordas moved to [[Denver]] in 1971.{{cite web |url= http://www.denverpost.com/2009/06/01/bordas-named-2009-unique-woman-of-colorado/|title= Bordas named 2009 Unique Woman of Colorado|first=William|last=Porter|date=1 June 2009|accessdate=15 June 2017|work=[[The Denver Post]]}} In 1976 she helped found the Mi Casa Resource Center for Women, which she led as executive director for the next decade. In 1987 she co-founded the National Hispana Leadership Institute, which grooms Latinas for leadership roles on the national level. She was president of the Institute for its first seven years.{{cite web |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/lifestyle/blogcritics/article/Interview-with-Juana-Bordas-Author-of-The-Power-4609442.php|title= Interview with Juana Bordas, Author of 'The Power of Latino Leadership: Culture, Inclusion, and Contribution'|first=Mayra|last=Calvani|date=18 June 2013|accessdate=15 June 2017|work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]}} She was also the first Latina faculty member of the Center for Creative Leadership, and the first Hispanic certified psychiatric social worker in Colorado. In 1993 she introduced the Latino Leadership Development Program, which provides individual assessments and coaching for Latinos interested in contributing to private and community initiatives. In 1995 she established the consulting firm Mestiza Leadership International, which provides diversity training and leadership programs in the workforce.{{cite web |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2003/08/18/focus7.html|title= Training tomorrow's Hispanic leaders is Bordas' goal|date=17 August 2003|accessdate=15 June 2017|work=[[American City Business Journals#Newspapers|Denver Business Journal]]}} In 2002 she debuted the Circle of Latina Leadership, which runs a nine-month community leadership development course and personal mentoring program for women aged 25 to 40. Bordas is a motivational speaker and workshop facilitator for many public and private organizations. She was the Fall 2008 Scholar in Residence at [[Frostburg State University]].{{cite web |url= https://www.frostburg.edu/dept/lead/scholar-in-residence-program/scholar-in-residence-program/#bordas|title= Leadership Residency Program – Biographies|publisher=[[Frostburg State University]]|accessdate=15 June 2017}} ==Affiliations and memberships== Bordas has served as an advisor for the ''Hispanic Journal on Public Policy'' at [[Harvard University]] and the Kellogg National Fellows Program. She was vice chair of the [[Robert K. Greenleaf|Greenleaf Center for Servant Leadership]], and a trustee of the International Leadership Association and [[Union Institute & University]].{{cite web |url=http://community.myunion.edu/juana-bordas-elected-union-institute-university-board-trustees/|title=Juana Bordas elected to Union Institute & University Board of Trustees (press release)|date=6 July 2014|accessdate=15 June 2017|publisher=[[Union Institute & University]]}} In 1993 she was considered for the post of Peace Corps director by the [[Presidency of Bill Clinton|Clinton administration]];{{cite web |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-937164.html|title=AIDS Policy Director Post Put 'On Hold' As President Ponders Duties, Details|first=Al|last=Kamen|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=15 March 1993|accessdate=15 June 2017|subscription=yes|via=HighBeam}} the position was ultimately filled by [[Carol Bellamy]].{{cite web |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1993/07/02/Bellamy-named-head-of-the-Peace-Corps/4879741585600/|title=Bellamy named head of the Peace Corps|date=2 July 1993|accessdate=13 July 2017|publisher=UPI}} ==Works== Bordas published her first book, ''Salsa, Soul, and Spirit: Leadership for a Multicultural Age'', in 2007. The book presents eight principles of multicultural leadership gleaned from Latino, African American, and Native American cultures.{{cite journal|url=http://pubs.lib.umn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1018&context=ijps|title=Intergalactic Leadership: Practical Tips for Leading Where No One Has Gone Before|journal=Interdisciplinary Journal of Partnership Studies|volume=2|issue=1|date=July 2015|first=Peg A.|last=Lonnquist|page=5}} It also profiles leaders from those backgrounds. In the book, Bordas mentions a common impediment for educational advancement in the Latino community called the "crab syndrome":
My parents wanted to protect me; they struggled with my decision to leave home to attend college. They were also afraid that once I left, I wouldn't come back. This tendency to hold on to people for safekeeping, which sometimes prevents them from leaving, is commonly known as the crab syndrome by many people in communities of color.{{cite web |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1559975561.html|title=Hispanic Parents and the Crab Syndrome|first=Marisella|last=Veiga|date=8 September 2008|accessdate=15 June 2017|work=The Hispanic Outlook in Higher Education|subscription=yes|via=HighBeam}}
Bordas' second book, ''The Power of Latino Leadership: Culture, Inclusion, and Contribution'', was published in 2013. Centering on Latino issues, the book sets forth ten principles of Latino leadership gleaned from the culture. Both books were "well-received by minority and corporate leadership experts". ''Salsa, Soul, and Spirit'' won the 2007 International Latino Book Award for best leadership book, and ''The Power of Latino Leadership'' received the 2014 Nautilus Award for best multicultural/indigenous book{{cite web|url=http://www.nautilusbookawards.com/2014_GRAND_GOLD_Winners.html|title=2014 Nautilus Award – Grand and Gold Winners|publisher=Nautilus Book Awards|accessdate=15 June 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170326141006/http://www.nautilusbookawards.com/2014_GRAND_GOLD_Winners.html|archivedate=26 March 2017|df=}} and the International Latino Book Award for best business/leadership book. ==Awards and honors== Bordas was inducted into the [[Colorado Women's Hall of Fame]] in 1997. She has received numerous awards and honors, including the 2006 Leadership Legacy Award from the Spellman College Center for Leadership; the 2008 Martin Luther King Jr. Social Responsibility Award; the 2009 Unique Woman of Colorado from ''[[The Denver Post]]'' and the Women's Foundation of Colorado; the 2015 Colorado's Most Influential and Powerful Women from the Colorado Diversity Council; the Outstanding Women in Business Award from the ''[[American City Business Journals#Newspapers|Denver Business Journal]]''; and the Franklin Williams Award from the Peace Corps for "lifelong commitment to advancing communities of color".{{cite web |url=http://www.juanabordas.com/about.html|title=About Juana Bordas|publisher=juanabordas.com|accessdate=15 June 2017}} [[Union Institute & University]] gave her an honorary [[Doctor of humane letters]] in 2009.{{cite web |url=http://community.myunion.edu/category/union-institute-university/page/5/|title=Union Institute & University recognizes excellence with the Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters|first=Mark |last=Barczak|date=30 August 2016|accessdate=17 June 2017|publisher=[[Union Institute & University]]}} ==Personal life== Bordas has three daughters. ==Bibliography== *{{cite book|url= https://books.google.co.il/books?id=fZjFngEACAAJ |title= Salsa, Soul, and Spirit: Leadership for a Multicultural Age|year=2007|publisher=Berrett-Koehler Publishers |isbn= 1576754324}} (2nd revised edition pub. 2012) *{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.il/books?id=BOHRND3efwAC&printsec=frontcover |title=The Power of Latino Leadership: Culture, Inclusion, and Contribution |year=2013|publisher= Berrett-Koehler Publishers |isbn=1609948874}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nkg3zl_CVQA "Juana Bordas Interviewed by Latina Voices"] November 21, 2013 *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vxKYzLPpZYs "Speech About Diversity"] July 15, 2013 *[http://www.ila-net.org/Publications/Proceedings/1999/jbordas.pdf "Latino Leadership: Moving into the Future"] Paper presented at the 1999 annual conference of the International Leadership Association {{Authority control}} {{Colorado Women's Hall of Fame}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bordas, Juana}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Leadership training]] [[Category:Hispanic and Latino American women]] [[Category:University of Florida alumni]] [[Category:University of Wisconsin–Madison alumni]] [[Category:Writers from Tampa, Florida]] [[Category:Writers from Denver]] [[Category:Nicaraguan activists]] [[Category:Nicaraguan emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:American women writers]]

{{Infobox person |name= Juliette Derricotte |image= Juliette-Derricotte.jpg |caption= Juliette Derricotte, graduation, 1918 |occupation= {{plainlist| * Educator * Dean of Women, [[Fisk University]] }} |birth_name= |birth_date= {{Death date|1897|4|1}} |birth_place= [[Athens, Georgia]], US |alma_mater= {{plainlist| * [[Talladega College]] * [[Columbia University]] }} |death_date = {{Death date and age|1931|11|7|1897|4|1}} |death_place= [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]], US | parents= |spouse= |children= }}
'''Juliette Derricotte''' (April 1, 1897 – November 7, 1931) was an [[African-American]] educator and political activist whose death after receiving racist treatment after a fatal car accident in [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]], sparked outrage in the African-American community. At the time of her death she was Dean of Women at [[Fisk University]].
==Early life==
She was born in [[Athens, Georgia]], the fifth of nine children of Isaac Derricotte and Laura Derricotte, a [[shoemaking|cobbler]] and a [[seamstress]]. As a child, she was hopeful of attending the local Institute and was crushed when her mother told her she would be unable due to her color. This event helped shape Juliette's perception of the world and her desire to change people's racial prejudices.<ref>{{cite book|last=Rummel|first=Jack|title=African-American Social Leaders and Activists|year=2003|publisher=Facts On File|isbn=0-8160-4840-1|page=55}}</ref>
==Education and career==
Her drive for education helped land her in [[Talladega College]], where she ended up getting a scholarship for her public speaking. After she graduated in 1918, she enrolled at the [[Young Women's Christian Association]] (YWCA) Training School. She then became the YWCA secretary of the National Student Council. Her responsibilities included visiting colleges, planning conferences, and fostering ideas and leadership. She is credited with recreating the council in ideology, helping it become more balanced, open, and most importantly, interracial.<ref>{{cite book|last=Anthony, III|first=David Henry|title=Max Yergan: Race Man, Internationalist, Cold Warrior|year=2006|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=978-0814707043|pages=128–131}}</ref>
In 1924, Derricotte became a member of the [[World Student Christian Federation]] and began traveling the world as a delegate representing [[United States|American]] colleges. In 1927, she received a master's degree in religious education from [[Columbia University]]. She resigned her YWCA position in 1929 to become Dean of Women at [[Fisk University]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Jones|first=William M|title=The Will of Man|year=2007|publisher=Xlibris Corporation|isbn=978-1-4257-9683-9|page=29}}</ref><ref>Lauren Kientz Anderson, [https://books.google.com/books?id=lY3foPCsUJ8C&lpg=PA9&dq=lauren%20kientz%20anderson&pg=PA9#v=onepage&q=lauren%20kientz%20anderson&f=false "A Nauseating Sentiment, a Magical Device, or a Real Insight? Interracialism at Fisk University in 1930"], in Marybeth Gasman and Roger L. Geiger (eds), ''Higher Education for African Americans Before the Civil Rights Era, 1900-1964'', Perspectives on the History of Higher Education, Vol. 29, New Brunswick, NJ: Transaction Publishers, 2012, pp. 75–111.</ref>
Derricotte was an active member of [[Delta Sigma Theta]], and was affiliated with the sorority's first graduate chapter in New York City. After her death Delta established a scholarship fund in her honor, it would be awarded to members of the sorority who are employed in the social work field.
==Deadly discrimination== Derricotte died in a traffic accident in [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]], in 1931. While she was riding in a car driven by a student, they collided with a white couple. Both Derricotte and the student were seriously injured. Although they received emergency treatment from white doctors, they were refused admittance to the local hospital because they were black. They were moved to a local woman's house, and both died by morning. This triggered national outrage and several investigations, one involving the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Lewis|first=David Levering|authorlink=David Levering Lewis|title=[[W. E. B. Du Bois, 1919-1963: The Fight for Equality and the American Century]]|year=2001|publisher=Holt Paperbacks|isbn=978-0-8050-6813-9|pages=297, 298}}</ref>
==Legacy== In the 1930s, [[Sue Bailey Thurman]] who had been inspired by Derricotte's ideas about learning and travel, established a scholarship fund, the Juliette Derricotte Scholarship, which allowed African-American undergraduate women of high academic achievement to study and travel abroad. One of the recipients of her scholarship was [[Margaret Bush Wilson]], who revived the fund decades later.<ref name="Juliette Derricotte">{{cite web|last1=DiMauro|first1=Susan|title=The Juliette Derricotte Scholarship: From the Desk of Margaret Bush Wilson|url=http://wulibraries.typepad.com/bears_repeating/2013/03/the-juliette-derricotte-scholarship-from-the-desk-of-margaret-bush-wilson.html|website=Washington University Libraries|publisher=Washington University|accessdate= August 4, 2015|location=St. Louis, Missouri|date=March 27, 2013}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
== Further reading == * {{cite book| author=Marion Cuthbert| title=Juliette Derricotte| publisher=The Woman's Press| location=New York| year=1936}}
== References == * [[Abdul Alkalimat|Alkalimat, Abdul]] (2004). ''The African American Experience in Cyberspace''. [[Pluto Press]]. {{ISBN|0-7453-2222-0}}. * [http://www.bookrags.com/biography/juliette-derricotte/ Encyclopedia of World Biography] * [http://www.tangledwire.com/Backhistory/Notables2.htm Notable African American Women] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070804175310/http://blackatlanta.net/juliettederricotte.html BlackAtlanta.net]
== External links == * [http://eblackstudies.org/ eBlack Studies]
{{Authority control}}

page.title: Khazar University School of Humanities and Social Sciences

revision.text:
{{Infobox university |name = The School of Humanities and Social Sciences |image_name = |logo = |established = 1992 |type = [[Private school|Private]] |affiliation = [[Khazar University]] |dean = [[Jabir Khalilov]], SJD |city = [[Baku]] |state = |country = [[Azerbaijan]] |students = |faculty = |staff = |campus = |website = [http://www.khazar.org khazar.org] }}
The '''Khazar University School of Humanities and Social Sciences''' ('''SHSS''') is the largest academic division at [[Khazar University]] and offers undergraduate and graduate degree programs in a wide range of disciplines. The primary language of instruction and research is English and the curricula correspond to the standards of leading higher education institutions in the West. Students, faculty and researchers are capable of keeping pace with global developments in their fields, using best practices and effectively communicating with scholarly communities all over the globe. Its degree programs are highly respected and recognized throughout the region.
==History== The idea of the School of Humanities developed in a year after [[Khazar University]] was founded. The importance of nourishing the younger generation of specialists in humanities was prioritized by the University in 1992 and several departments were established henceforth.
The school chose as its mission learning, preserving and spreading Azerbaijani national and cultural values embedded in our heritage as well as appreciating diversity and welcoming universal values. In 2004, the idea of merging the School of Humanities with several departments at the School of Law and Social Sciences was discussed; in 2005 the School of Humanities transformed into the School of Humanities and Social Sciences.
The School of Humanities and Social Sciences (SHSS) is the largest academic division at Khazar University and offers undergraduate and graduate degree programs in a wide range of disciplines. At SHSS students have an opportunity to gain knowledge and polish skills across a variety of disciplines in Humanities and Social Sciences, including languages and literatures, [[Political Science]], International Affairs, [[History]], [[Journalism]], [[Religious Studies]] and [[Philosophy]] programs. In addition, a wide range of courses are offered in Sociology, Psychology, and Anthropology.
==Programs== In addition to well-developed Bachelor programs in English Language/Literature, Translation Studies, and [[Journalism]], the Bachelor of Arts in English/[[Arabic]] and in English/[[Persian language|Persian]] are offered by the Department of English and the Department of Eastern Languages and Religious Studies.
The Bachelor of Arts in Journalism/English is an interdepartmental degree program offered jointly by the Department of [[Journalism]] with the Department of English.
The Department of Political Science and International Relations offers undergraduate and graduate degrees in [[Political Science]] with concentration in Political Theory, Peace and Conflict Studies, and [[Area Studies]], such as Middle Eastern Studies and European Public Affairs. The Department also offers separate degree programs in International Relations, both on undergraduate and graduate levels.
The programs leading to the Master of Arts degree include Linguistics, [[Area Studies]], [[Political Science]], [[International Relations]], Translation Studies, [[Journalism]], Interlingua Relations.
The preparations are underway to initiate undergraduate and graduate degree program majors and minors in [[Philosophy]], [[Psychology]], [[Applied Arts]], [[Music]] and other fields.
===Undergraduate programs=== {| class="wikitable" |- | '''1''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Bachelor of Arts in English/[[Arabic]] |- | '''2''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Bachelor of Arts in English/[[Persian language|Persian]] |- | '''3''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Bachelor of Arts in English Translation/[[Arabic]] |- | '''4''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Bachelor of Arts in English Translation/[[Persian language|Persian]] |- | '''5''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Bachelor of Arts in Journalism/English |- | '''6''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Bachelor of Arts Program in [[Political Science]] |- | '''7''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Bachelor of Arts in [[Area Studies]] |- | '''7''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Bachelor of Arts in [[Psychology]] |- | '''7''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Bachelor of Arts in English Language Teaching |- |}
===Graduate programs=== All students admitted into the graduate programs with a BA degree must enter the MA course of study, which also serves as the first phase of the Ph.D. program. Then Ph.D. programs are developed for students with strong research interest in the field. The students admitted to non-English graduate should take at least two English language courses (minimum of 6 credits) offered by the English Language and Literature Department if their level of English is not advanced.
====Master and Ph.D. degree programs==== {| class="wikitable" |- | '''1''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|English Language and Literature |- | '''2''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Linguistics (applied/general) |- | '''3''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Area Studies (Asian Studies, European Studies, Middle East Studies, American Studies, and other regions of the world) |- | '''4''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|International Relations |- | '''5''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Political Science |- | '''6''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Translation Studies |- | '''7''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Translation Theory and Inter-lingual Relations |- | '''8''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|Journalism |- | '''9''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|World Literature / Comparative Literature |}
==Education quality==
The SHSS has an excellent reputation. The faculty of SHSS is drawn predominantly from teachers and scholars with solid Western European and North American training. Since the primary language of instruction and research is English and the curricula correspond to the standards of leading higher education institutions in the West, students, faculty and researchers are capable of keeping the pace with global developments in their fields, using best practices and effectively communicating with scholarly communities all over the globe. Its degree programs are highly respected and recognized throughout the region.
==Alumni== Graduates of the SHSS are highly regarded in Azerbaijan and around the world. The SHSS alumni work for state and social institutions. Among the top national employers are the President’s Administration, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Internal Affairs, and the Ministry of Education. Most of the school graduates work for leading local academic institutions.
==SHSS affiliated academic departments== {| class="wikitable" |- | '''1''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|'''Department of English Language and Literature''' |- | '''2''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|'''[[Khazar University Department of Political Science and International Relations|Department of Political Science and International Relations]]''' |- | '''3''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|'''[[Khazar University Department of Eastern Languages and Religions Studies|Department of Eastern Languages and Religions Studies]]''' |- | '''4''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|'''[[Khazar University Department of History and Archaeology|Department of History and Archaeology]]'''
|- | '''5''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|'''Department of Journalism''' |- | '''6''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|'''Department of Modern Languages and Comparative Literature''' |- | '''7''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|'''Department of Music and Fine Arts''' |- | '''8''' | bgcolor=FFE4B5|'''Department of Philosophy and Human Studies''' |- |}
==References== {{reflist}} *Khazar University Catalog 2008-2009, [[Khazar University Press]].
==External links== *[http://www.khazar.org/ Khazar University website] *[http://www.hisaxanli.org/ Prof. Hamlet Isakhanli]

{{DEFAULTSORT:Khazar University School Of Humanities And Social Sciences}} [[Category:Khazar University]] [[Category:Universities in Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Education in Baku]] [[Category:Schools of international relations]] [[Category:Area studies]] [[Category:Private universities and colleges]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2012}} Practices in [[language education]] vary significantly by region. Firstly, the languages being learned differ; in the [[United States]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] is the most popular language to be learned, whereas the most popular languages to be learned in [[Australia]] are [[Italian language|Italian]] and [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin Chinese]]. Also, [[Methods of teaching foreign languages|teaching methods]] tend to differ by region. [[Language immersion]] is popular in some European countries, but is not used very much in the [[United States]].
==Europe==
===Foreign language education=== 1995 [[European Commission]]’s White Paper "Teaching and learning – Towards the learning society", stated that "upon completing initial training, everyone should be proficient in two Community foreign languages". The Lisbon Summit of 2000 defined languages as one of the five key skills.
In fact, even in 1974, at least one foreign language was compulsory in all but two European member states: [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] and the [[United Kingdom]] (apart from [[Scotland]]). By 1998 nearly all pupils in [[Europe]] studied at least one foreign language as part of their compulsory education, the only{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} exception being the Republic of Ireland, where primary and secondary schoolchildren learn both [[Irish language|Irish]] and [[English language|English]], but neither is considered a foreign language although a third European language is also taught. Pupils in upper secondary education learn at least ''two'' foreign languages in [[Belgium]], [[France]], [[Denmark]], [[Netherlands]], [[Germany]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Finland]], [[Sweden]], [[Iceland]], [[Switzerland]], [[Greece]], [[Croatia]], [[Cyprus]], [[Estonia]], [[Latvia]], [[Lithuania]], [[Poland]], [[Romania]], [[Serbia]], [[Slovenia]] and [[Slovakia]].
On average in Europe, at the start of foreign language teaching, pupils have lessons for three to four hours a week. Compulsory lessons in a foreign language normally start at the end of [[primary school]] or the start of [[secondary school]]. In Luxembourg, [[Norway]], [[Italy]] and [[Malta]], however, the first foreign language starts at age six, in [[Sweden]] at age seven and in Belgium at age 10. About half of the EU's primary school pupils learn a foreign language.
English is the language taught most often at lower secondary level in the EU. There, 93% of children learn English. At upper secondary level, English is even more widely taught. [[French language|French]] is taught at lower secondary level in all EU countries except [[Slovenia]]. A total of 33% of European Union pupils learn French at this level. At upper secondary level the figure drops slightly to 28%. [[German language|German]] is taught in nearly all EU countries. A total of 13% of pupils in the European Union learn German in lower secondary education, and 20% learn it at an upper secondary level.
Despite the high rate of foreign language teaching in schools, the number of adults claiming to speak a foreign language is generally lower than might be expected. This is particularly true of native English speakers: in 2004 a [[United Kingdom|British]] survey{{which|date=November 2010}} showed that only one in 10 [[United Kingdom|UK]] workers could speak a foreign language. Less than 5% could count to 20 in a second language, for example. 80% said they could work abroad anyway, because "everyone speaks English." In 2001, a European Commission survey{{which|date=November 2010}} found that 65.9% of people in the UK spoke only their native tongue.
Since the 1990s, the [[Common European Framework of Reference for Languages]] has tried to standardize the learning of languages across Europe (one of the first results being [[UNIcert]]).
===Bilingual education=== {{Main|Bilingual education}}
In some countries, learners have lessons taken entirely in a foreign language: for example, more than half of European countries with a [[minority language|minority]] or [[regional language]] community use partial immersion to teach both the minority and the state language.
In the 1960s and 1970s, some central and eastern European countries created a system of bilingual schools for well-performing pupils. Subjects other than languages were taught in a foreign language. In the 1990s this system was opened to all pupils in general education, although some countries still make candidates sit an entrance exam. At the same time, Belgium's French community, [[France]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Austria]] and [[Finland]] also started bilingual schooling schemes. [[Germany]] meanwhile had established some bilingual schools in the late 1960s.
==United States== {{main|Language education in the United States}} In most school systems, foreign language is taken in [[high school]], with many schools requiring one to three years of foreign language in order to graduate. In some school systems, foreign language is also taught during middle school, and recently, many elementary schools have begun teaching foreign languages as well. However, foreign language immersion programs are growing in popularity, making it possible for elementary school children to begin serious development of a second language.
In 2008 the Center for Applied Linguistics conducted an extensive survey documenting foreign language study in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cal.org/content/download/2241/29054/version/2/file/ForeignLanguageExecutiveSummary.pdf|title=Foreign Language Teaching in U.S. Schools: Results of a National Survey|last1=Rhodes|first1=Nancy C.|last2=Pufahl|first2=Ingrid|publisher=Center for Applied Linguistics|date=November 2009|accessdate=7 July 2018}}</ref> The most popular language is [[Spanish language|Spanish]], due to the large number of recent Spanish-speaking immigrants to the United States (see [[Spanish in the United States]]). According to this survey, in 2008 88% of language programs in elementary schools taught Spanish, compared to 93% in secondary schools. Other languages taught in U.S. high schools in 2008, in descending order of frequency, were [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], [[Latin language|Latin]], [[Standard Mandarin|Mandarin Chinese]], [[American Sign Language]], [[Italian language|Italian]], and [[Japanese language|Japanese]]. During the [[Cold War]], the United States government pushed for [[Russian language|Russian]] education, and some schools still maintain their Russian programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0405/p11s02-legn.html|title=You learned Russian - in high school?|last=Méndez|first=Theresa|date=5 April 2005|publisher=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=7 July 2018}}</ref> Other languages recently gaining popularity include [[Arabic language|Arabic]]. The Center for Applied Linguistics also conducted a study that concluded that while the number of schools from the elementary to secondary level offering foreign language instruction are on the rise, a pitfall of the curriculum is that students are not becoming proficient in the target languages.<ref>{{cite web|last=Pufahl|first=Ingrid|title=What We Can Learn From Foreign Language Teaching In Other Countries|url=http://www.cal.org/resources/digest/0106pufahl.html|publisher=Center for Applied Linguistics|accessdate=8 May 2012}}</ref> Researchers also note that American students of foreign languages significantly underperform in comparison to their European and Asian counterparts. It has been suggested that a system where foreign language instruction is required from PK-12 should be implemented in order to fix this problem.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cognitive Benefits of Learning Language|url=http://www.actfl.org/i4a/pages/index.cfm?pageid=4724|publisher=Online Newsletter for Parents of Gifted Youth|accessdate=8 May 2012}}</ref>
==Australia== Prior to European colonisation, there were hundreds of [[Australian Aboriginal languages|Aboriginal languages]], taught in a traditional way. The arrival of a substantial number of [[Irish language|Irish]] in the first English convict ships meant that European Australia was not ever truly monolingual. When the [[Australian gold rushes|gold rushes]] of the 1850s trebled the white population, it brought many more [[Welsh language|Welsh]] speakers, who had their own language newspapers through to the 1870s, but the absence of language education meant that these Celtic languages never flourished.
Waves of [[Post-war immigration to Australia|European migration after World War II]] brought "community languages," sometimes with schools. However, from 1788 until modern times it was generally expected that immigrants would learn English and abandon their first language.<ref>Clyne, 1997.</ref>{{broken citation|date=March 2011}} The wave of [[Multiculturalism in Australia|multicultural policies]] since the 1970s has softened aspects of these attitudes.
In 1982 a bipartisan committee of Australian parliamentarians was appointed and identified a number of guiding principles that would support a National Policy on Languages (NPL). Its trend was towards bilingualism in all Australians, for reasons of fairness, diversity and economics.
In the 1990s the Australian Languages and Literacy Policy (ALLP) was introduced, building on the [https://books.google.com/books/about/National_Policy_on_Languages.html?id=IGIcAQAAIAAJ NPL], with extra attention being given to the economic motivations of second language learning. A distinction became drawn between priority languages and community languages. The ten priority languages identified were [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]], [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], [[Modern Greek]], [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]], [[Japanese language|Japanese]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Korean language|Korean]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Australian Aboriginal languages|Aboriginal languages]].
However, Australia's federal system meant that the NPL and ALLP direction was really an overall policy from above without much engagement from the states and territories. The NALSAS strategy united Australian Government policy with that of the states and territories. It focused on four targeted languages: Mandarin, Indonesian, Japanese and Korean. This would be integrated into studies of Society and Environment, English and Arts.
By 2000, the top ten languages enrolled in the final high school year were, in descending order: Japanese, French, German, Chinese, Indonesian, Italian, Greek, Vietnamese, Spanish and Arabic. In 2002, only about 10% of Year 12 included at least one [[Languages other than English|language other than English]] (LOTE) among their course choices. In 2009, Lo Bianco and Slaughter, recommended a new approach, stating that “What is needed is a universal apprenticeship in learning how to learn languages”.<ref>{{cite book | title=Second Languages and Australian Schooling | author=Lo Bianco, J | year=2009 | publisher=Australian Council for Educational Research}}</ref> An apprenticeship language is a relatively easy language which is taught to overcome the limitations of monolingualism, in preparation for later mastery of a different language or languages.
Reasons to use an apprenticeship language are:{{Citation needed|date=June 2015}}
* To make a start when target language teachers are unavailable. * To master a whole foreign language, for motivation and effective subsequent learning. * To combat procrastination in the face of diverse priorities in Language education. * To normalize bilingualism and promote flexibility. * To model creative problem solving, ethical behaviour and global citizenship.
A resource and method has been devised to implement the ALL approach by equipping generalist primary (elementary) teachers to teach the simple designed language [[Esperanto]] as a [[Propaedeutic value of Esperanto|first, fluent, intercultural, foreign language]].<ref>{{cite book | title=Talking to the Whole Wide World: Integrated LOTE and Intercultural Studies for Australian Primary Schools | author=Vos, P | year=2010 | publisher=Mondeto}}</ref>
The professional body for teachers of foreign languages in Australia is the [[Australian Federation of Modern Language Teachers Associations]].
==Japan== {{Main|English language education in Japan}}
==Hong Kong== Native [[Cantonese]]-speaking Hong Kong children commence learning English and maybe also [[Mandarin_Chinese|Mandarin]] from age 3 when they go to kindergarten and continue until they finish their secondary education.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} The [[Hong Kong government]]'s language policy is to produce people who are [[biliterate]] in English and [[Written Chinese]] and [[trilingual]] in Cantonese, Mandarin and English. In order to enter university in Hong Kong, students must pass both English and Chinese exams, or in the case of those who did not learn Chinese at school, due to having studied at an [[international school]], another foreign language.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}
==United Kingdom==
Since 2014 it has been compulsory for [[primary school]] children to be taught at least one language.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-15135560 |title=BBC News - Teach foreign languages from age five, says Gove |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=October 1, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Lepkowska |first=Dorothy |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/schools/an-innovative-scheme-is-helping-primary-teachers-brush-up-their-language-skills-2230676.html |title=An innovative scheme is helping primary teachers brush up their language skills - Schools - Education |publisher=The Independent |date=March 3, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2012}}</ref> <ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-26713090</ref> In 2004 it was no longer compulsory for secondary school pupils to have to study a foreign language at GCSE level.<ref>{{cite web|last=Richardson |first=Hannah |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-12243936 |title=BBC News - Gove: 'Door open' for compulsory foreign language GCSE |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=January 20, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Language education]] [[Category:Language education by country]]

revision.comment: Changed date of off-Broadway revival of Cradle will Rock from 1962 to 1964, per separate Wikipedia article on that musical play.
revision.text:
{{For|the drummer|Lori Peters}} {{No footnotes|article|date=April 2009}} {{Infobox person | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1943|7|2}} | birth_place = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], U.S. | occupation = Actress | years_active = 1959–1973 | spouse = {{marriage|[[Jon Voight]]
|1962|1967|reason=div.}} }} '''Lauri Peters''' (born '''Patricia Peterson'''; July 2, 1943) is an American actress, dancer, singer, drama teacher and author. Peters created the role of Liesl Von Trapp in the original 1959 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production of ''[[The Sound of Music]]''. She received a [[Tony Award]] nomination for Best Supporting or Featured Actress in a Musical, which she shared with her sibling castmates. She was married to actor [[Jon Voight]] (1962–67), whom she met when he joined the cast as [[Nazi]] messenger boy Rolfe, with whom Liesl has a song ("[[Sixteen Going on Seventeen]]") and a mutual attraction. She can be heard on the show's cast album, which has sold more than three million copies in the US. In Britain, she is probably best known as [[Cliff Richard]]'s romantic lead in the 1963 film ''[[Summer Holiday (1963 film)|Summer Holiday]]''. On film, she also acted alongside [[Fabian (entertainer)|Fabian]], [[James Stewart]] and [[Sidney Poitier]]. She also appeared as Moll in the revival of [[Marc Blitzstein]]'s ''[[The Cradle Will Rock]]'' directed by [[Howard Da Silva]]. She appeared on popular television shows of the 1960s and '70s, including ''[[Gunsmoke]]'', but worked primarily in the theater, on and off Broadway, and in touring companies. With acting teacher [[Sanford Meisner]], Peters founded the Meisner Extension at [[New York University|NYU]] in 1993, where she was Artistic Director and Master Teacher. Teaching the technique away from Manhattan, she has written a book on Meisner. ==Musical theatre== *1959 ''[[First Impressions (musical)|First Impressions]]'' *1959 ''[[Sound of Music]]'' as ''Liesl Von Trapp''. *1964 ''[[The Cradle Will Rock]]'' as Moll ==Film== *1962 ''[[Mr. Hobbs Takes a Vacation]]'' *1963 ''[[Summer Holiday (1963 film)|Summer Holiday]]'' *1968 ''[[For Love of Ivy]]'' ==External links== *{{IMDb name|676555}} *{{IBDB name}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Peters, Lauri}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American stage actresses]] [[Category:American film actresses]] [[Category:American television actresses]] [[Category:Drama teachers]] [[Category:Actresses from Detroit]]

contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.text:
{{Update|date=January 2014}}
[[File:Flag of Europe.svg|right|200px]]
The '''Lifelong Learning Programme 2007–2013''' (previously referred to as the "Integrated action programme in the field of lifelong learning" or the "Integrated programme") is the [[European Union]] programme for education and training.
==Introduction== The Lifelong Learning Programme 2007–2013 was established by ''Decision No.1720/2006/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 November 2006''.<ref>Official Journal of the [[European Union]] No L327 of 24 November 2006 [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2006/l_327/l_32720061124en00450068.pdf]</ref> It is the single financial instrument available to the Commission for its directly managed education and training policies during the period covered by the [[European Union]]'s current [[financial perspective]]. The Programme continues the main actions launched under previous action programmes (in particular, it brings together the various actions financed under the [[Socrates programme]] and the [[Leonardo da Vinci programme]]). It has six sub-programmes:
*The [[Comenius programme]], supporting actions for schools (from pre-primary schools to upper secondary or equivalent) *The [[Erasmus programme]], supporting exchanges of students in [[higher education]], as well as cooperation between universities and colleges, etc.; *The [[Leonardo da Vinci programme]], supporting actions in initial and continuing [[vocational education|vocational education and training]] (including student and apprentice exchanges, cooperation between colleges, etc.) *The [[Grundtvig programme]], supporting actions in the field of [[adult education]] *The [[Transversal programme]] covering activities in four themed areas across all sectors of education and training: policy cooperation and innovation in education and training; [[Second language acquisition|foreign language teaching]]; development of ICT-based content and services, such as Euroguidance and [[Ploteus]];<ref>{{cite web|title=Lifelong Learning Program |publisher=European Union Pprograms Agency |url=http://llp.eupa.org.mt/content.php?id=27 |accessdate=15 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120530203736/http://www.llp.eupa.org.mt/content.php?id=27 |archivedate=30 May 2012 |df= }}</ref> and dissemination of results of the programme; *The [[Jean Monnet Programme]], supporting institutions and actions in favour of [[European integration]].
==Objectives== The Programme's objectives<ref>cf article 1.3 of the decision</ref> are first, to support the development of quality [[lifelong learning]] (a reference to the first paragraphs of Articles 149 and 150 of the [[Treaty of Rome]], which establish the European Union's duties in education and training in those terms); and thereafter to help [[member states of the European Union]] develop their own [[Education|education and training systems]]. Although the objectives are expressed in somewhat abstract terms, they are underpinned by actions which concentrate on the creation of links between people, institutions and countries in education and training – what the programme describes as the "European Dimension" of education and training.
==Actions supported== The programme supports exchanges and connections between people, institutions and countries within the [[European Union]] and the [[European Economic Area]].
===Exchanges between individuals=== These include (for example):
*Erasmus Student exchanges of between 3 and 12 months, in which students leave their home university and follow an agreed part of their course at another university in another country. No additional fees are payable, and the course is recognised by the home institution as part of course-work for the degree. Over 150,000 students did Erasmus student exchanges in the academic year 2005/6, and the cumulative total since 1987 is over 1,500,000.<ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/education/news/erasmus20_en.html Erasmus website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703000422/http://ec.europa.eu/education/news/erasmus20_en.html |date= 3 July 2007 }}</ref> *In-service training courses in school or adult education. The Comenius and Grundtvig programmes support participation in specific short <ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/education/trainingdatabase/|title=EUROPA - Socrates Comenius|website=ec.europa.eu}}</ref> work placements (internships) for vocational students in companies in another country, to help them complete their skills<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/education/programmes/llp/structure/fiches/leonardo1_en.pdf|title=cf 2007 description at|publisher=}}</ref>
===Exchanges between institutions=== These include (for example):
*Developing partnerships between schools in different countries ("Comenius partnerships") to run joint projects for and with their pupils.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/education/programmes/llp/structure/fiches/comenius6_en.pdf|title=cf 2007 description at|publisher=}}</ref> *Similar projects are supported in the field of adult education by the [[Grundtvig programme]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/education/programmes/llp/structure/fiches/comenius6_en.pdf|title=cf |publisher=}}</ref> *Joint projects run by universities in different countries to develop joint curricula, run short-term intensive programmes, or establish thematic networks in different disciplines<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eacea.ec.europa.eu/static/en/overview/erasmus_overview.htm|title=Erasmus Overview|website=eacea.ec.europa.eu}}</ref>
===Connections between countries=== These include (for example):
*Study visits for regional and national administrators in education, training and guidance <ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/education/programmes/llp/structure/fiches/pol1_en.pdf|title=Leonardo da Vinci<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=}}</ref> *Networks of national experts working together on issues of common interest.<ref>cf the network on ICT in education and training; example of a report at [http://ec.europa.eu/education/doc/reports/doc/ictimpact.pdf] or the History Network providing materials and guidelines for researching, teaching and learning European History [http://www.cliohworld.net/ CLIOH-WORLD]</ref> *Publication of comparable statistics indicating how the various education and training systems are progressing.<ref>cf the [[European Commission|Commission's]] annual "progress report": 2006 version at [http://ec.europa.eu/education/policies/2010/doc/progressreport06.pdf]</ref>
==Programme mechanics== The management of the programme is very largely decentralised to a network of "national agencies", nominated by the participating countries.<ref>http://ec.europa.eu/education/programmes/llp/national_en.html</ref> All individual mobility schemes and partnerships, and many multilateral projects, will be funded through these agencies. A limited number of projects will be handled centrally either by the [[European Commission]] itself or through its [[Education, Audiovisual and Culture Executive Agency]] – a public agency funded by the Commission and operating on its behalf.<ref>http://eacea.ec.europa.eu/index.htm</ref>
==Funding== The Programme has an indicative total budget of €6.970 billion over the seven years 2007–2013. Minimum seven-year allocations for each of the four bigger programmes are laid down<ref>cf Annex B.11 of the decision</ref> as follows:
*Comenius: 13% (€0.906 billion) *Erasmus: 40% (€2.788 billion) *Leonardo da Vinci: 25% (€1.743 billion) *Grundtvig: 4% (€0.279 billion)
The remaining budget is to be spent on other actions and administrative costs. Experience of previous programmes suggests that the final seven-year budget will slightly exceed the current estimate<ref>As was the case for the previous [[SOCRATES programme|Socrates]] and [[Leonardo da Vinci Programme]].</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.logisticsqualifications.eu/] CENTRAL project : Certification for Employment iN Transport and Logistics in Europe *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130730072946/http://ec.europa.eu/education/programmes/newprog/index_en.html European Union — The Lifelong Learning Programme 2007–2013] *[http://www.lifelonglearningprogramme.org.uk/index.asp UK - The Lifelong Learning Programme 2007-2013] *[http://ec.europa.eu/dgs/education_culture/eve/ Eve is the single information point on European education, training, culture and youth projects] *[http://www.adam-europe.eu/adam/homepageView.htm ADAM, the project and product portal for Leonardo da Vinci] *[http://www.europeansharedtreasure.eu/ EST, the database for Partnerships projects in Comenius, Leonardo da Vinci and Grundtvig] * [http://www.popullar.eu/ European Union funded education project "PopuLLar - Music and Language Learning" (acronym PopuLLar)] * [http://www.web20erc.eu/ European Union funded project Web2.0 European resource centre (acronym Web2.0ERC) ] * [http://www.aplanet-project.eu/ European Union funded education project "Autonomous Personal Learning Networks for Language Teachers" (acronym aPLaNet)] *[http://www.arg-education.eu ARGUing for Multilingual Motivation in Web 2.0] - funded project within the Comenius programme, using an [[Alternate Reality Game]] to motivate language learning * [http://www.cliohworld.net/ CLIOH-WORLD] CLIOH-WORLD: Network of Universities supported by the European Commission (LLP-Erasmus) for the researching, teaching and learning of the history of the EU, including History of EU Integration, EU-Turkey dialogue, and linking to world history.
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lifelong Learning Programme 2007-2013}} [[Category:Educational policies and initiatives of the European Union]] [[Category:Vocational education]] [[Category:Lifelong learning]]

page.title: List of Clarion South Writers Workshop Instructors

revision.text:
This is a list of instructors in the [[Clarion South Writers Workshop]], an annual writers' workshop for science fiction, fantasy, and speculative literature writers.
* [[Lee Battersby]] (2007) * [[Simon Brown (author)|Simon Brown]] (2007) * [[Jack Dann]] (2009, 2004) * [[Ellen Datlow]] (2005) * [[Terry Dowling]] (2004) * [[Gardner Dozois]] (2007) * [[David G. Hartwell]] (2004) * [[Rob Hood|Robert Hood]] (2007) * [[Nalo Hopkinson]] (2004) * [[Ian Irvine]] (2005) * [[Trent Jamieson]] (2009) * [[Margo Lanagan]] (2009, 2007, 2005) * [[Kelly Link]] (2007) * [[Lucy Sussex]] (2004) * [[Michael Swanwick]] (2005) * [[Jeff Vandermeer]] (2009) * [[Scott Westerfeld]] (2005) * [[Kim Wilkins]] (2004) * [[Sean Williams (author)|Sean Williams]] (2009, 2005)
==See also== * [[List of Clarion South Writers Workshop Alumni]] * [[Clarion Workshop]] * [[List of Clarion Writers Workshop Instructors]] * [[List of Clarion Writers Workshop Alumni]] * [[Clarion West Writers Workshop]] * [[Clarion South Writers Workshop]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox museum | name = National Folk Museum of Korea {{Infobox Korean name|child=yes |hangul=국립민속박물관 |hanja={{linktext|國|立|民|俗}}{{linktext|博物館}} |rr=Gungnip Minsok Bangmulgwan |mr=Kungnip Minsok Pangmulgwan }} | image = Korea-Seoul-National.folk.museum-01.JPG | imagesize = 230 | caption = View of the National Folk Museum building. | alt = | map_type = | map_caption = | map_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|37|34|54|N|126|58|45|E|region:KR-11_type:landmark_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=inline}} | established = 1924 | dissolved = | location = Samcheongdong-gil 35, [[Jongno-gu]], [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]] | type = | collection = | visitors = 1,813,626 (2017)The Art Newspaper Review, April 2018
[[List of most visited art museums in the world|Ranking 31st globally]] | director = Shin Gwang-seop | president = | curator = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | network = | website = [http://www.nfm.go.kr:8080/english/main.jsp www.nfm.go.kr] }} [[File:National Folk Museum of Korea.jpg|thumb|280x280px]] [[File:Interior of a traditional Korean house.JPG|thumb|Interior of a traditional Korean house, National Folk Museum]] '''National Folk Museum of Korea''' is a national museum of [[South Korea]], located within the grounds of the [[Gyeongbokgung Palace]] in [[Jongno-gu]], [[Seoul]], and uses replicas of historical objects to illustrate the history of traditional life of the Korean people.{{Cite news|url=http://asemus.museum/museum/national-folk-museum-of-korea/|title=National Folk Museum of Korea - Asia-Europe Museum Network|work=Asia-Europe Museum Network|access-date=2017-11-14|language=en-US}} ==History== The museum was established on 8 November 1945 by the U.S. Government and opened on 25 April 1946 at the City Administration Memorial Hall. When the museum was merged with [[National Museum of Korea]], its collection of 4,555 artifacts was moved to the latter's [[Namsan (Seoul)|Mt Namsan]] site. In 1975, when the National Museum moved onto the grounds of [[Gyeongbokgung Palace]], it moved along with it into the Modern Art Museum Building. In 1993 it opened in its present site, which was the former site of the National Museum of Korea. The building's design is based on various historical buildings around South Korea.NFMK [http://www.nfm.go.kr:8080/english/htm/muse2_history.htm History: The National Folk Museum of Korea] Retrieved 2011-11-04 ==Collection== The museum has three main exhibition halls, with over 98,000 artifacts: '''History of Korean People''' features materials of everyday life in Korea from prehistoric times to the end of the [[Joseon Dynasty]] in 1910; '''Korean Way of Life''', which illustrates Korean villagers in ancient times; and '''Life Cycle of the Koreans''', which depicts the deep roots of Confucianism in Korean culture and how this ideology gave rise to most of the culture's customs. The museum also features open-air exhibits, such as replicas of spirit posts where villagers used to pray, stone piles for worship, grinding mills, rice storage shelters and pits for kimchi pots. CNN Go [http://www.cnngo.com/seoul/play/seouls-best-museums-060516 Seoul's best museums] 27 October 2011. Retrieved 2011-11-04 ==See also== *[[History of Korea]] *[[List of museums in Seoul]] *[[List of museums in South Korea]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|National Folk Museum of Korea}} *[http://www.nfm.go.kr/language/english/main.jsp] {{en icon}} [[Category:Jongno District]] [[Category:Museums established in 1945]] [[Category:Folk museums in South Korea]] [[Category:Children's museums]] [[Category:Museums in Seoul]] [[Category:National museums of South Korea]] [[Category:Child-related organizations in South Korea]] {{Korea-museum-stub}}
